block.p: Soviet officials threatened Lithuania with reducing or cutting off natural gas and crude oil supplies. The threat prompted calls in the republic's Parliament for scaling back measures toward independence.

President Bush then warned Moscow that he would retaliate for a cut in fuel shipments to Lithuania. Administration officials said possible responses range from canceling exchanges to stalling trade talks.
The Soviet criminal justice system came under rare review in the Parliament. A special commission criticized two former criminal prosecutors and suggested that the prosecutor general be dismissed.
Visit by Soviet writers sparks debate over anti-Semitism
NATO allies still lag on arms, Pentagon study says
West Germany's Deutsche Bank A.G. announced that it would jointly establish an East German bank with Deutsche Kreditbank A.G., the first private commercial bank in East Germany.
U.S. official says contra camps will be dismantled this week
Court freezes U.S. bank accounts thought to hide drug profits
Pretoria won't accept majority rule but is prepared to negotiate a formula for whites to share power with blacks in South Africa, President de Klerk announced.
The political leader of the Zulus in South Africa, both widely admired and detested, is a force with which President de Klerk and Nelson Mandela must reckon as they negotiate the nation's future.
Eleven die in clashes between Shiite Muslims in West Beirut
Thousands of Burmese are fleeing advances by Burmese troops against rebellious ethnic minorities along the Thai border, creating a new refugee problem for Thailand.
Nepal's fledgling political parties, which emerged after King Birendra lifted a 30-year ban on politics, are reveling in freedom and denouncing the Government without fear.
New Delhi Journal: A revolutionary among India's poor

Consumer prices climbed in March by five-tenths of 1 percent to make the annual inflation rate 8.5 percent for the first three months of 1990, the most rapid increase in a quarter in nearly eight years.
Citicorp says earnings fell 56 percent in first quarter

The Supreme Court supported unions by ruling that permanent replacements hired during a strike need not be presumed to be anti-union for purposes of deciding whether the union still has majority support.
Use of drugs in religious rituals can be prosecuted, court rules

A buried treasure in Puerto Rico? In the town of Vega Baja, F.B.I. agents are looking for leads after residents uncovered drums stuffed with as much as $20 million. Residents who enjoyed a giddy spending spree are reluctant to share details.
A gene that is linked to alcoholism has been indentified for the first time, scientists reported. The finding holds promise for the prevention and treatment of alcoholism.
A rise in AIDS cases in rural Georgia has caught many health officials by surprise, confronting them with difficult choices on how to provide care and testing community values.

Washington at Work: Party loyalty? Representative Constance Morella of Maryland voted against her Republican colleagues 76 percent of the time. She does not get many invitations to the White House, but neither is she shunned.
A Catholic anti-abortion campaign worth $3 million to $5 million has sharply divided employees at Hill & Knowlton, the public relations firm hired to conduct it.
Mayors press Bush for support to avert census crisis
F.D.A contradicts its report on antibiotics in milk
San Francisco's worst eyesore, many people believe, is the monstrous Embarcadero Freeway. The earthquake may well have rectified that, but controversy has arisen over how to replace it.
Twin Peaks Journal: Town relishes television notoriety
New York's air quality has delcined again after years of improvement. With more automobiles spewing pollutants into the city's atmosphere, only Los Angeles has dirtier air.
Bush calls for more research on global warming

Fear follows Bronx livery drivers after the recent wave of killings. Scores of livery cars clogged the 225th Street Bridge to demand stronger police action. ''You can't trust anybody,'' one driver said.

The New Jersey Attorney General ordered the grand jury investigation of the fatal shooting of a black youth by a white policeman in Teaneck moved to the state level because of mounting tension in the community.
Bid for a special prosecutor is rejected in Teaneck shooting
Bensonhurst trial defendant admits group gathered with bats

News analysis: Conflicts of interest for Mayor Dinkins and City Council President Andrew Stein over cable television franchises have put both men in the unusual position of asking staff members to vote ''independently'' in their place.
Matinee day in New York City lures to Broadway dozens of suburban groups, organized by churches, schools and social clubs. For many, matinee day is one of the few chances they have to visit the city.

Scheduled passenger service began at Stewart International Airport. The state, which owns the former Air Force base at Newburgh, hopes it will spur economic growth in the region, but still faces opposition from environmentalists.
Baruch College's re-accreditation had been deferred
Witness says commissions were routine in Marcos dealings
New York City pension trustees criticize A.T.&T.
Star chefs are on the outside looking in
U.S. bars Kobe beef from Japan
How children helped to save the tunas
NBC stays on top of the ratings
Theater: A Soviet portrayal of an unsaintly but heroic Lenin
Music: Solisti New York Chamber Orchestra
Word and Image: Virginia Woolf's letters
Cubs beat Mets in extra innings
Column: Vecsey on Eddie Lee Wilkins
Modest campus blazes trail to business careers
Ralph David Abernathy, pioneer in rights struggle
Cloud over cable in New York
John Ralston Saul: Drugs, torture - and Western cash
Richard Pollock: Census - getting the lead out
